learning_objective: Design and iteratively develop computational artifacts for practical intent, personal expression, or to address a societal issue by using events to initiate instructions.
question_str:
{
    "Question": "Alex is designing an application that uses real-time data to inform users about the air quality in their immediate vicinity. Alex's program has an array of air samples taken every hour for a week. Here is a snippet of Alex's code:Which of the following provides the correct explanation for how Alex's code executes when an 'unhealthy' reading is detected?",
    "Answer1": "This code will print the unhealthy air quality message once and then stop the program.",
    "Answer2": "This code will send a notification to the user every hour when the air quality is unhealthy.",
    "Answer3": "This code will ignore the unhealthy air quality readings.",
    "Answer4": "This code will only send a notification to the user if the air quality has been unhealthy for a week.",
    "CorrectAnswer": "2",
    "Explanation": "The loop in Alex's code executes once every hour, checking the air quality each time. If an 'unhealthy' reading is detected, it will trigger an event that sends a notification to the user. This will continue to occur every hour as long as the air quality remains 'unhealthy'.",
    "code_snippet": "integer i = 0\nwhile i < length of airSamples\n    if airSamples[i] == 'unhealthy'\n        output 'The air quality is currently unhealthy. Please take appropriate precautions.'\n    end\n    i = i + 1\nend "
}
